cip.title: Critical Infrastructure Protection (CIP)
cip.text: Official standards created under order of the government and direction of NERC that give utilities guidance on how to protect the North American Electric Bulk Electric System from cyber-attack.

bes.title: Bulk Electric System (BES)
bes.text: The significant power plants, transmission lines, and associated equipment that make up North American's large interconnected electrical system. Excludes distribution systems.

nerc.title: North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC)
nerc.text: NERC is a non-profit formed by utilities to improve the reliability of the Bulk Electric System and secretly tasked by the government to prepare the industry for the coming metallic onslaught.

high.title: High Impact
high.text: High Impact facilities are large Control Centers and Backup Control Centers. This includes data centers that house cyber assets used for Control Center operations.

medium.title: Medium Impact
medium.text: Medium Impact facilities are significant generation plants, transmission stations and substations, and smaller control centers.

low.title: Low Impact
low.text: Low Impact facilities are the smaller plants, transmission stations and substations, and other control centers not classified as High Impact and Medium Impact.

cyber_assets.title: Cyber Assets
cyber_assets.text: Programmable electronic devices, including the hardware, software, and data in those devices. These includes control systems, relays, servers, workstations, laptops, handheld devices, and anything else that acts like a computer.

bca.title: BES Cyber Assets (BCA)
bca.text: Servers, workstations or other programmable devices that will cause real-time operational problems for the Bulk Electric System if they are hacked, attacked, or disabled. Examples include: control systems, energy management system servers, relay devices, and operator workstations.

pca.title: Protected Cyber Assets (PCA)
pca.text: Any servers, workstations, or other programmable devices connected to the same network as BCA but that don't have a real-time impact on the Bulk Electric System. Examples might include: file servers, network printers, and tape backup servers.

bcsi.title: BES Cyber System Information (BCSI)
bcsi.text: Information useful for an attacker planning an attack. Examples include maps, security plans, network diagrams, and configuration information stored on hard drives, file shares, and in filing cabinets.

crca.title: CIP-Related Cyber Assets (CRCA)
crca.text: A single term that used to cover all the crazy CIP acronyms for assets that have security requirements. CRCA is used to refer to these asset types: BES Cyber Assets, Protected Cyber Assets, Electronic Access and Monitoring Systems, and Physical Access Control Systems.

electronic_access.title: Electronic Access
electronic_access.text: The ability to logon to workstations, servers, and other CRCAs.

physical_access.title: Physical Access
physical_access.text: The ability to open a door and enter a Physical Security Perimeter. Essentially, this means you have physical access to CRCAs.

manager.title: CIP Senior Manager
manager.text: Leads the CIP war efforts against the robots and our allies. Be sure to greet them with the official Fist-Bump SaluteTM if you pass in the hallway.

defenders.title: Defenders
defenders.text: Individuals like you who have access to and are responsible for, maintain, support, or use CRCAs and BCSI. Examples: IT Manager, Network Tech, Substation Tech, System Operator, Control Room Operator, Flak-Cannon Engineer.

cyber_security_program.title: Cyber Security Program
cyber_security_program.text: A document that describes how our people and defenses meet the CIP Standards. Auditors will use the Program document to evaluate our defenses. This training and your duties as a Defender is based on the Program.

psp.title: Physical Security Perimeter (PSP)
psp.text: The physical border surrounding locations in which CRCAs reside. This border is typically made up of walls, fences, and doors. Access through doors and other access points must be controlled.

esp.title: Electronic Security Perimeter (ESP)
esp.text: The logical border surrounding a network to which CRCA are connected. Electronic communication into and out of the ESP network must be controlled.

information_access.title: Information Access
information_access.text: The ability to access file shares, filing cabinets, and other locations that have BCSI.

user_account.title: User Account
user_account.text: An account that a Defender uses to verify their identity and log into a workstation, server, or other kind of CRCA. These accounts often use a username and password to verify the person, but other methods can be used.

shared.title: Shared Account
shared.text: An single login account used by multiple employees.

default.title: Default Account
default.text: An account that comes pre-configured by the manufacturer on a CRCA. These are commonly administrative accounts and sometimes share the same user name and password on all manufactured devices.

brute.title: Brute-Force Attack
brute.text: A trial-and-error method where an attacker tries to guess a user's password. Automated software is used to generate a large number of consecutive guesses.

visitor.title: Visitor
visitor.text: Visitors are anyone who doesn't have Physical Access to a PSP but we want to allow them to go inside for tours, gauge reading, audits, and other short-term needs.

visitor_escort.title: Visitor Escort Procedure
visitor_escort.text: A procedure that ensures Visitors are documented, monitored, and continually escorted by a Defender at all times while inside a PSP.

cyber_security_incident.title: Cyber Security Incident
cyber_security_incident.text: Any malicious or suspicious event that attempts to disrupt the real-time operations of the Bulk Electric System.

team.title: Incident Response Team
team.text: A group of Defenders gathered to coordinate the response to a cyber-attack.

csirp.title: Cyber Security Incident Response Plan
csirp.text: A plan that gives guidance for how Defenders at an organization respond to a Cyber Security Incident.

recovery.title: Recovery Plan
recovery.text: A plan that defines the data backups, spare equipment and parts, and steps needed to restore each type of CRCA after an attack.

eisac.title: Electricity Information Sharing and Analysis Center (E-ISAC)
eisac.text: This organization is the primary security communications channel for the electricity sector and helps us prepare for and respond to cyber and physical threats, vulnerabilities, and incidents.

vulnerability_assessment.title: Vulnerability Assessment
vulnerability_assessment.text: A process that identifies security holes (vulnerabilities) in our systems. Includes a security analysis of networks, CRCAs, and other systems an attacker may try to compromise.

config.title: Monitoring Our Defenses
config.body: Given enough effort, any moat can be bridged and any wall breached if defenders aren't ready to repel the enemy. This episode is about how we detect and respond to Cyber Security Incidents - actual attacks against our infrastructure.

config.title: Keep a Sharp Lookout
config.body:
All Defenders must be on the lookout for shady persons photographing our facilities, attempting to gain information via phone, email or other means, and doing otherwise shifty things. Disappearance of vehicle passes, personnel identification, uniforms, or BCSI is also suspicious.

Further, if you have Electronic Access to CRCAs, keep an eye out for anything that doesn't seem right on your system. This includes windows or messages that you don't recognize, unusual system slowdowns, files out of place, or otherwise strange system behavior.

Report any of these promptly because an attack may be in progress.

config.title: Electronic Monitoring
config.body:
Nearly all of our CRCAs generate events that may be indications of an attack. Unauthorized access, firewall alerts, failed logins, unexpected system changes, and detection of malicious code are just a few examples.

Our technical Defenders - like Richard - must monitor and analyze these events to detect if they represent a Cyber Security Incident. In addition, they will perform regular Vulnerability Assessments on our defenses to proactively look for security problems.

config.title: Guard Duty
config.body: All this monitoring is a big job that requires involvement from all Defenders, so let's learn our duties.

config.title: Local and National Response
config.body:
When our monitoring efforts detect an attack, the Standards require that we convene an Incident Response Team to coordinate our efforts to repel the attackers and a Cyber Security Incident Response Plan with processes that ensure we handle an attack swiftly and effectively.

An incursion on our territory might be part of a larger, coordinated attack against the Bulk Electric System, so our Incident Response Team must promptly report significant incidents to E-ISAC, the organization that coordinates response to attacks at the national level.

config.title: Maintaining Readiness
config.body: We must test our Cyber Security Incident Response Plan yearly with a simulation and use our lessons-learned to improve the plan. Other events may cause the Plan to change - like employees moving out of roles - so we must keep the information in the plan up-to-date.

config.title: No Need for Simulation
config.body:
Many of us will have defined roles on the Incident Response Team, help approve the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan, or be involved in yearly testing. During an actual attack, any Defender may be called upon for support, so we must all be ready.

Our facility Defenders have already been detecting and responding to Cyber Security Incidents in each simulated attack, so we'll skip the simulator for this chapter.

a.text: Skip the simulation? So confident aren't we? CIP has my robots all figured out, doesn't it?

b.text: All words and no action, Sektimus. We are waiting for an attack that will defeat our CIP-secured facility.

c.text: Your wait is over. I'm uploading scripts that contain an attack your Cadet cannot defeat.

d.text: WarCore, can you scan this signal for Malware?

e.text: Scanning. Signal Clean. CTANLEE, these appear to be simple parameters for configuring my simulator with a new attack.

g.text: Cadet, are you ready to put your facility to the test?

items.btnTxt: Bring it on and bow to my facility.

d.text: [Low chuckle] A little surprise just for you old friend.

f.text: The Incident Response Team has been convened. This is definitely a Cyber Security Incident.

g.text: How are they going to respond?

i.text: Good call, team. Get the people out.

k.text: [chuckles] I'll now accept your concession CTANLEE, and your resignation from the training program, human. [still chuckling]

m.text: Not so fast, Sektimus. The wager was against all the CIP Standards and we still have one training chapter left.

n.text: [chuckles] It matters not. Complete your worthless training. I'll observe.

o.text: Hold your head high, Cadet. We're not beaten yet.

config.title: The Recovery Plan
config.body:
After an attack, assets may be damaged (or incinerated), so we must have a Recovery Plan that helps our Defenders restore functionality quickly. The Recovery Plan defines the data backups, spare equipment and parts, and steps needed to restore each type of CRCA. The Plan also guides Defenders on how to preserve forensic data from the attack useful for subsequent investigations.

We are expected to keep our Recovery Plan up-to-date and test it yearly, often concurrently with the yearly test of our Incident Response Plan. We must also regularly test that our data backups are working and usable for recovery purposes.

config.title: Yes We Can!
config.body: Defender, it's time to put our Recovery Plan into action and repair our facility.

b.text: CTANLEE, this means nothing. I'll just send my Bot-Tron back.

d.text: Defender, please pick your NERC Bot-Tron Defense.
What is this [enraged]? This isn't fair! These defenses don't exist.

e.text: The WarCore is simply simulating the results from following the CIP Standards. Our Incident Response Team reported the Bot-Tron attack to E-ISAC and NERC used the information to build new experimental defenses for the industry against Bot-Tron Overlords. Proceed with your selection, Cadet.

config.title: Choose your NERC Bot-Tron Defense
config.subTitle:
The Incident Response Team reported the threat to E-ISAC. From this information and the forensic data we provided from the recovery, NERC designed several Bot-Tron Overlord defenses.
Time to kick some bot.

items.btnTxt: Brit Beacon, Scholar. Gentleman. Bot Hunter.
items.blurb:
Moustache Length: +4 inches
Rifle Name: Lord Brimstone
items.details:
Dog's Bullocks! Hire NERC's greatest living robot fighter (and his legendary rifle) from the other side of the pond to take care of your robot problem. The first human to ever kill a Bot-Tron Overlord, he's not called the Can Opener for nothing.
Robots need to be shot and by Jove, I'm the one to shoot them!

items.blurb:
Tow Cable Length: 800 meters
Last deployed: Planet Hoth
items.details:
Imported by NERC from a galaxy far, far away, these reconfigured speeders have already seen action against many-limbed attackers like our Bot-Tron Overlord. Travelling around a Bot-Tron ain’t like dustin’ crops, but pilot Harrison Groundrunner will bring this thing to its knees … errr joints.
"Witness the power of this fully operational tow cable!"

items.blurb:
Size: Classified
Use: Classified
Material: Classified
Launching Satellite: Classified
items.details:
Part of NERC's secret [Classified] program, this weapon drops [Classified] rods from satellites. Gravity increases the speed of the rods to Mach [Classified] until they impact the target causing [Classified]-level destruction. [Classified] guidance system ensures precision targeting.
"When you care enough to send the very best"

config.title: Choose your NERC Bot-Tron Defense
config.subTitle:
The Incident Response Team reported the threat to E-ISAC. From this information and the forensic data we provided from the recovery, NERC designed several Bot-Tron Overlord defenses.

b.text: No, no no no no. Nooooooo!
Perhaps I was … premature … in my earlier judgment. Human, you performed at a higher level than I calculated possible. You are a worthy opponent.

c.text: So much the better. I prefer a good challenge.

d.text: I will keep my eyes on you - all of them. My swarm is not far and we shall meet again on the real battlefield.

e.text: Not many have the courage to stare Sektimus in the eyes and challenge him. Well fought. Let's complete your training.

b.text: Our training comes to an end…

c.text: …and you have earned the title of Defender.

d.text: I know you will wear this title and perform your duties with honor.

e.text: Now it's time for you to leave the WarCore and protect your infrastructure.

f.text: but You will not be alone in this fight. Even now many Defenders are being prepared to stand with you.

h.text: …and at many other organization just like yours.

i.text: You and your fellow Defenders truly are this planet's greatest hope.

b.text: Now go out and protect your infrastructure. Farewell, Defender.
